reviewText: I COULD NOT WAIT UNTIL I RECEIVED THE LAST AND FINAL SEASON OF ENTOURAGE AND WHEN I DID I WAS NOT DISAPPOINTED AT ALL. THANK YOU AMAZON ONCE AGAIN.

I have had no issues with any of the seasons of Entourage, and this one was no exception. I still feel like the ending was a lead in to a future movie because the ending leaves you hanging with doors left WIDE open (make sure to watch the little bit after the end credits of the final episode). Seriously, this series could have gone on forever and I'm sad to see it end so I'm hoping for a movie or two in the coming years! One issue I have is Vince's spontaneous decision near the end which I didn't totally buy at all and felt it was rushed. In regards to the actual blu-ray quality it isn't the greatest. There is a lot of grain in a lot of the scenes and it's sometimes distracting. It's still an improvement over the DVD, including the sound which is more crisp, clearer and louder. Oh yeah and fyi, Mrs. Ari's name is finally revealed as Melissa.

The other reviews I've seen talk about how this was a rushed season and yes, it was.  However I thought it was common knowledge that the season was rushed and ended suddenly and without conclusion because they were making a movie to finish up the series and the unanswered questions/unresolved plot lines.

This was a good season overall with a lot of good episodes from 1-7.  The last episode was definitely mediocre but this is understandable as they wanted to leave the story open ended as to resolve it with the movie.  Not a spin off, not just trying to rush the series to an end... a movie.

With all that being said this was still a very short season and in my opinion should by no means cost the same or more than the other full sized seasons.  I would not recommend buying this in pre-order or right when it comes out for full price.  It's just not worth it to me for only eight episodes for which to really get the full effect and resolution of those episodes you'll have to buy the movie as well making the cost even higher.

Reference for Entourage movie can be found here: [...]
as well as many many other locations just by using any search engine.

I love Entourage. I have watched all 7 seasons almost 4 times. The characters are hilarious. Yes this season has it's downs but life isn't perfect and I think they did a good job. If you don't like the way it ends suck it up there will be two movies that explain the rest of the story. Yes they did rush it a little bit but maybe they did that so they can jump right into the movies and make it a little more interesting and try to please everybody. (which is impossible) Everything evolves.
The show kelp me entertained for 8 seasons and no matter what the critic say we love it in my household thanks for the laughs farwell.

"Entourage" is about Hollywood and about friendship, and so it's really nothing at all.  "Entourage" is by season eight completely out of gas, and season seven cliff-hanger is that A-list celebrity Vincent Chase has been -- gasp! -- busted for using drugs.  It's clear that the real star is neither Vincent Chase (who plays very well an actor who cannot act and who has no personality) or even his entourage, but his agent Ari Gold, who is what ultimately keeps the show going.  Halfway through the season everyone is bored and tired, and just wants to move on with their lives so they do what anyone else in Los Angeles would find himself in the same situation would do -- they move to New York City.

I grew up a big fan of Entourage, In fact I enjoy every now and then to watch it all over since I have all previous seasons. My only issue with season 8 or series finale was the fact they were rushing it since season 7, don't forget that season has only 10 episodes. I think the whole deal for the finale was nicely done but rushed out. Believe me a lot of people will be bitching and complaining about how all of a sudden Vince gets married with the british girl. Producers not even developed that story line. In my humble opinion if they had reached 12 episodes instead 8 they would accomplished a little bit more.

This is another season that will divide fans because everyone has their own opinion about how the season was supposed to end.

Of the eight episodes of this shortened season, I thought that the first seven were fantastic. However, the series finale ended with a whimper instead of a bang.

Let's start with its good aspects and end with the less positive ones:

(1) The First Seven Episodes - Every character had major conflicts that he needed to resolve in this season.  Johnny Drama is on the cusp of starring in a television show that could rival the "Simpsons" and "Futurama" in terms of its popularity.  But, he will have to mediate between the strong wills of his co-star, Andrew Dice Clay, and his producer to push the project through. Turtle could make a name for himself as he spear-heads the U.S. launch of Avion tequila; however, despite his street-smarts and enthusiasm, he may not have the business acumen needed to turn a profit.  As far as Eric ("E") is concerned, he has changed. We all believed that E was a nave minnow trying to protect his friend, Vincent Chase, from the shark-tank that is Hollywood. By this season, we discover that E is a shark himself. Some of his actions this season are so breathtakingly manipulative and cynical that we have to wonder if he has lost his soul.  As E loses his soul, Ari Gold struggles to find his. Once again, Jeremy Piven turns in an acting tour de force, as Ari ponders his life as a potential divorcee. What does a man in his mid-40s with all that clout, intelligence and ambition do when he has suddenly lost the family that kept his darker impulses in-check? This season we get to find out and the end-result is fascinating. Finally, we see yet another side of Vincent Chase. Vince is clean and sober after a court-mandated rehab stint. Internalizing the lessons of his sobriety support group, Vince decides that he is going to enrich the lives of those around him --- by any means necessary. Vince's aggressively good-intentioned meddling in the lives of others has both some awkwardly comedic and shockingly tragic ramifications.  Overall Grade for these 7 episodes: A -minus)

(2) The Final Episode - The series finale seemed disjointed and oddly anti-climatic. This is particularly unfortunate since there were four episodes in the final season which are amongst the best of the series.  HBO, as a whole, has been very hit-or-miss in how it concludes series. The finale to the Sopranos ended abruptly. While ambiguity can be a good thing,that finale seemed to do the series a disservice. Conversely, the finale to Six Feet Under was one of the best I have ever seen. I would place Entourage in the Sopranos category; its clumsy attempt to tie up loose ends will probably have a negative impact on how this season is viewed. (Overall grade for the final episode: D - plus)

With all of this said, Entourage was a great series and I will certainly will miss it.

Season seven was bad. But season eight is just horrible. I could understand trying to go a different direction in season seven to continue the show, but why go so far away from the show's roots in a final season.

The entire season is bad relationship melodrama with nothing else. There is nothing interesting. It is the opposite of fun.

Vince gets involved with what seems like a character left over from an unmade chic flick. You know, the bright uptight reporter from the big city who doesn't like the guy at first but then suddenly decides to instantly marry him without really even knowing him.

Sloan (the boat-anchor of the show) whines her way through another season. And just when it seems that she is finally gone, they bring in a shotgun wedding to fix everything. Its really sad. They spend the whole season creating situations as to why she and Eric should not be together. Then put them together for the worst possible reason.

And then we get a whole lot more Ari family drama. Its all derivative and repetitive from last season. And in the end, all the problems are solved by Italian singers and moving to Italy. Whatever.

In each case, the reasoning is terrible. In each case, the man is completely at fault, the man must give up his friends, the man must give up his career. Its like they had a season of leftover sex-and-the-city scripts. I came away from the last episode thinking "three inevitable divorces" rather than happy ending.

The whole drug thing from last season ends up going in an unexpected direction. Vince goes to treatment for a little while and everything is all better. No real consequences to speak of at all.

The problem with Jeremy Piven as Ari Gold is that he only really knows how to play an agent. He transitions to different jobs in the series but the job and how he acts in the job is always the same. Thats not true to business. The things they never really show is (a) him dealing with a younger "ari" (what he used to be like) in his own company, (b) the implicit conflicts of interest in running a big company with lots of clients and (c) Vince isn't as important in the big picture to him as he was.

Vince undercuts Drama and Turtle's attempts to strike out on their own by helping each in the wrong way. Turtle in particular ends up looking like an idiot. Some of the stuff with Drama is interesting, but having him get pushed around by Andrew Dice Clay wasn't. It would have been better, in my opinion, for Drama to have been the one holding out with ADC & Billy pushing him to settle.

Somewhere along the way, they lost track of what made entourage fun and why people liked the show. Why with eight episodes left they decided to do a whole season about disfunctional relationships, is beyond me.

This is a very weird concluding season.  The vast proportion of time is spent on everyone's love life as every male in the show strives to end up happy ever after with the woman of his choice.  This is such a far cry from where this show began that I could scarcely believe it.  Judging from the prior season, I thought we were headed for a very dark, very grim ending instead.  This season resembles a romance novel more than anything else with its stress on finding happy ever after with true love, marriage, babies, etc.,  If the guys had all ended up monks in an abbey, I couldn't have been more surprised. To put it mildly, this is a very surprising twist in everyone's character arc from the prior 7 seasons.

For the show scenes not headed in that direction, we did have a few good moments.  Andrew Dice Clay became the co-star for Drama's cartoon tv series.  Drama and Clay have a huge stand off with the producers for more money.  This is very rooted in show business reality and Clay and Kevin Dillon are wonderful in this sub plot.

Vinny Chase has to pass a drug test and Billy comes up with a fake male appendage to use in the bathroom with the cop.  This fake is even filled with someone else's urine so that he will pass the test.  I found this whole sub plot very funny.

Vinny also tries to save a fellow drug abuser from going over the deep end. This "gentler, nicer, I want to be part of the solution" Vinny Chase ends up right on the edge of outright satire in his new personality.  Considering how the show concluded, I think the makers of this show took this conversion seriously but I found it satiric.

And then there is Jeremy Piven as Ari Gold.  We seem to resolve his problems too but after the credits are over, a new scene plays which presents a whole new career path for Ari.  Spin Off.  That's why ENTOURAGE is over is my guess.  They want Piven to star as Ari in his own series in a new Hollywood career. Stay tuned.

I watched the 1st season of Entourage back when in originally aired and then I think we quit paying for HBO and I got busy with life.  I remember liking that 1st season, but had forgotten all about it until I spent a few minutes with Prime in 2018 and came across my long lost series.  I just binge watched the entire 8 seasons in two days and am now watching it again.  Everyone has moved on, and I am wearing out Google catching up on all the buzz & history of Entourage.  Absolutely loved it!  I haven't seen the movie yet, think I'm gonna savor the series a little longer
what a great series, worth every minute to watch

I lived in Los Angeles my whole life and have first hand been around the Hollywood scene. I watched the movie on a connecting flight for fun thinking it was going to be all drugs, sex, and Hollywood, however I was wrong. This show is pure genius. I never had the chance to watch the show but I decided to give it a try. I know im about a decade late but I honestly have to say this show is by far one of my favorites and will forever be. Every single character has a special place in my heart. I honestly don't know how im going to coupe with coming home from work or the art studio and not being able to unwind and watch a couple episodes. Thank you, just thank you for a great performance and 8 great seasons. You know how they say you loose so much time in front of a screen or watching television...Not a minute lost. Sad to know its over but hey maybe in a couple months ill watch reruns just to get a laugh from Ari yelling at Lloyd or Jonny trying to pick up a girl. Thank you again to the cast and everyone behind this show. I know none of them will ever see this post or rating but you will forever be one of my favorite shows to hit the screens.

To the hopes of more,

Lauren Aubrey

I cancelled my subscription to HBO just before season 8 aired and have waited years to watch it.  Imagine my surprise when Amazon Prime picked it up this month.  I watched it immediately, it was so worth the wait.  Episode 1 Season 8 was slow, but it really picked up after that.  thoroughly enjoyed watching the Boys bring it home.

Clearly I love this - as I watched every episode - and a few years later, watched many again while labeling bottles of La Magie Organic Hair Serum.

This show is so beloved by so many because its characters have heart.  Our lead man, Adrian Grenier as Vincent Chase, is forgiving, understanding, compassionate and of course, gorgeous with undeniably beautiful blue eyes which I'm sure melt every woman who crosses his path. But he's not arrogant or conceited, he takes care of his friends with great generosity of heart, mind and wallet. His brother, Kevin Dillon, bro of Matt, as Johnny Drama, is hysterical as the he man but he has one of the more important roles in the show. For the one or two that "make" it in Hollywood, there are thousands, if not millions, of people who didn't get the lucky break, who don't have the long face that photographs well; who may have a dream but who lack talent. And, all of these people relate to Johnny when he tries again and again, and all rejoice when he finally "gets" the gig. And, ultimately, some of those gigs fell apart as many shows in Hollywood do that never quite make the race out of the gate.

Jeremy Piven as Ari Gold gives us insights into the "suits" that run Hollywood, the money men who truly have learned to make money out of thin air. I have a few times been privileged to watch this financial miracle unfold and really, no one has anything on Hollywood when it comes to financing. Most of the country could take lessons from these guys on creativity because when it comes to creating money, they can make it appear out of thin air and make it disappear just as fast. Back to Jeremy - he's absolutely wonderful giving voice to all the unspoken rages that so many of us feel but never speak.

Actually, I think Jeremy could give lessons in full body acting. I have never seen anyone throw their entire body into representing a feeling as well as Jeremy Piven does. Kuddos, it's a true joy to watch your character go up and down.

I have to give special love to Rex Lee who plays Lloyd. He is so adorable, witty, charming and let it not be forgotten, there is a huge power in the gay community in Hollywood. Some of the brightest lights, creative talents and pure genius reside there.

I love all the characters but I gotta get to work.

So, I'm giving season 8 five stars, but there is a huge condition attached. I'm giving it 5 stars largely because the friendship, the story, and the other seasons were so awesome. I still love "Entourage" as long as it's "Entourage." The premise, characters, and humor were so awesome, that I don't know how to give the show less than 5 stars. "Entourage" on a bad day is better than any show I know of on a good day.

That being said, this season was pretty weak, and the tone of it changed way too much, and went out of my comfort zone. It was disturbingly dark and "Entourage" and creator Doug Ellin don't do dark very well. Ellin and the show are unabashedly optimistic and fun, and the darkness just played awkwardly in seasons 7 and 8. I've heard people say that Doug Ellin essentially got lucky with "Entourage," and that his talent couldn't always keep up with the show's success, and I tend to think that's true. For example, seasons 7 and 8. The story lines were awkward, and didn't always even make sense. For example, Vincent Chase's head injury that caused his wild behavior. It was never addressed and never resolved. The problem just kind of disappeared when Ellin figured that enough dark stuff had happened, and when it was time to wrap the 8th season. I'm not sure if the writing was lazy, or if Ellin's lack of talent just caught up with him, and it was all the sound of a marginally talented guy running out of ideas and getting fatigued. The best episodes were written by two writers named Mark Abrams and Mike Benson. Doug Ellin did a decent job with plenty of the scripts and he really knew how to write Ari Gold, but his writing was only occasionally spectacular.

Handing the show off partly to writer Ally Musika was also a grave mistake. She turned the whole thing into a running soap opera drama that was too bitter, weepy, and feminine but it was partly Ellin's fault too for getting the ball rolling in that direction. Someone commented that Scott Caan was embarrassing to watch, and I partly agree. He had a good "masculine energy" that fit the show well, but he was really unlikable and didn't fit the vibe. He didn't really deserve a sacred spot close to the inner circle of the entourage. He truly was a douche, like his character, and while he had up and down qualities, I wouldn't have missed him if he weren't there.

Overall, season 8 sucked compared to the first 6 seasons but, it still being "Entourage," I give it 5 stars. Like I said, "Entourage" on a bad day is better than any other show on a good day.

For all of the testosterone on display in the preceding seven seasons of Entourage, the eighth and final season
REEKED of estrogen! What a wimpy, kum-by-yah, conclusion! Given that it was written and directed by (Eric) Kevin Connolly I guess it was par for the course. Actually, I like Kevin Connolly as an actor but, his character (Eric) must have taken over his writing skills. What "fluff!" The only thing missing was a pink ribbon at the end. Only die-hard fans will like the eighth season (somewhat).

By season 8, the characters are well defined, and play off each other brilliantly.  E has love trouble.  Vinny finds love that he actually has to work for.  Ari is finally accountable for the fact that he's the worlds most gigantic prick, and you loving him more for it.

Overall, this was a pretty satisfying season finale.  Not breaking bad, but more good times.  It's tough to see a good show like this go, but 8 seasons was enough.

I thought this season was lazy, so few episodes and it felt like the attitude when creating it was just 'hurry up and wrap up all the loose ends". The actors were great as always, so I guess it was the writing/directing that gave it this rushed feel. Sad it's over though, they had a great idea and executed the other 7 seasons flawlessly, so entertaining!

Really, I would expect at least 12 episodes, if not more. But it is what it is, and because I enjoyed the series as a whole, I'll give it 4 stars.

I binge watched all 8 seasons of Entourage and the last one really fell short. Vinnie Chase comes out of rehab only to be fawned over by his brother and friends. After that, so many conveniences ensue that one is left wondering just how lazy the writers could be. An super agent Ari Gold hits rock bottom, but his foul mouth antics go even lower, to the point that the language made me wince. There was no reason to be that disgusting. We already knew what his character was like and if he was going to redeem himself, then let him do it gradually and gracefully with a bit of reform here and there that could be perceived as an effort to be a better person instead of just a desperate guy pulling out all the stops. Then there Eric Murphy, whining and complaining, battling with Sloan until she drops a huge surprise in his lap. Eric is the least likable character, who also happens to take over an agency of his own with Scott Lavin (played well by Scott Caan). And even Lavin's character is just another foul-mouthed agitator. No range was exhibited in this season, except for maybe Johnny Drama who finally gets a decent break only to blow it, almost, due to differences with Andrew Dice Clay of all people. Turtle rises and falls and rises again, yes thanks to Vinnie's generosity. It all wraps up in a too-neat package with Vinnie falling in love in 24 hours. Seriously? Bed hopper Vinnie decides to lock in with one lady just like that? His rehab must have been something else! Oh, well, it had to end somewhere. I just wish it would have been at least 12 episodes instead of cheating us with 8, and the writers would have done their jobs with more effort.

THE GOOD- Drama's storyline provides the most laughs for the season.  Dice holding up the network for more money is consistent with his infamous ego.  It plays beautifully in this storyline with a tormented Drama must choose between a potential tv series or his loyalty to his friend Dice.  Ari's storyline was also very good and is given much funnier stuff than he was in season seven.  Most importantly, is the inclusion of Lloyd, who was reduced to a background character (I have no idea why) in season 7.  Scott (E's business partner) steals the season. He was hilarious as a dirty-minded sleazeball.
THE BAD-  E's storyline is flat out annoying.  With him and Sloan acting like two high school kids by saying they don't want to be in each other's lives anymore.  So, why are they always calling each other on the phone and paying visits to each other?  E acts uncharacteristically sleazy in this season and is not the sharp character he was in previous seasons.  They then add some unnecessary twist to E's story, which was probably done solely for the fact it was the show's last season.  Vince had a decent storyline going until it's god awful conclusion, which no fan bought for a mili-second.  Turtle never seems to pay for all his stupidity and poor business decisions.  Once again, Turtle walks out unscathed after making yet another business blunder.  The resolution of his story is equally preposterous as Vince's.  The last two episodes of this season are so slapdashed together it ruins the first six good episodes.
THE DEAL- Despite it's hokey finale, this season is funnier than season 7.  Had they done 12 or 13 episodes this would have been a much better season.  But even with 12 episodes or so, I still wouldn't have bought the lame conclusion they had for Vince.  They should have left it more open-ended instead of forcing a sense of closure.  That would have been better.  Also, it may have helped to close out by reinforcing the unity of the gang they will always be there for each other.  But the way it was concluded made that an impossibility.  A horrible ending for an otherwise good-very good show.

Watching Entourage makes me want to workout LOL. Never have I cried during an espisode of Entourage until the very last one of the series. I balled for probably the last 10 mins of the show. It was a great ending :)

Season 8 redeemed itself from season 7 that was a snooze fest! I won't spoil anything, but it was great and it left an opening for the future...Enough said!!!
One of my all time favorite TV series. Highly recommend all season of Entourage for anyone looking to find an entertaining tv series.

No Spoilers....  I will say though that I was disappointed in this season. I thought season 7 wasn't great but was not terrible. Season 8 in my opinion was terrible. The story lines simply were implausible and poorly developed. The season seemed rushed and quite frankly I thought it was disservice to what in my opinion was the best show on TV. Farewell my  entourage friends I wish we could have parted on higher note then season 8 but thats life..... Thanks for the many laughs throughout the years...
This was the last and weakest season, however, they still made me laugh.  So sad Diceman did not play a more comedic role.  I miss the "old" Diceman.

i am usually disappointed with the ending of series but this one proved me wrong
all was wrapped up and done with class
i would recommend this series to all
This series should have ended after season 6.  I love the characters and will probably go to the movie just to see them again.
The best show I will miss these guys and was not disappointed want to start from the beginning again must see
I have really enjoyed this series and will be sad that its over, but it was also time to end.

We liked all of Entourage series. They were light, fun, and different than our normal life.

We also enjoyed Season 8 with happy endings for each character.  They realized what was the most important in their lives at the end.
Love every season of Entourage.  The final season did not disappoint and leaves the show set up for a possible movie eventually.
What can you say about a series that was incredible.  Will miss these group of guys.  Bought the whole series for my boyfriend over the years for gifts.
Obviously the writers ran out of ideas.  The ending show was a real let down.  The entire season felt disjointed and played as if there were huge time losses.
Brand new item for less than the other stores, what more could you ask for. Another very good show on the air...to bad that it is the last season.
Best finale season for all eight seasons.  I would highly recommend purchasing Entourage.  Buy it! Crazy good but you have to watch it for yourself.
Enjoyed it.  Terrific picture and sound quality added to the enjoyment. Can't wait for the next season to be released

My only problem was that it was only 8 episodes. I loved this show - it is one of my favorites of all time. I love the characters and the way they interact with each other. I love all of the characters from Ari to Lloyd to Vince to E to Drama to Turtle to Sloan and Ms. Gold and the rest. They are fantastic (I love Ari the most). But only 8 episodes? Come on, HBO! I understand that Marky Mark was ready to move on to other projects so whatever.

Regardless, good season. The ending was a little disappointing but when you think about it, I couldn't really think of a better way for them to end the series. They had to put an end on it and they had to make it conclusive for all five of the main characters (I include Ari in that set). They had to put a conclusion on it and I think they did that as well as possible. Would you have preferred a mid-sentence breakaway a la Sopranos? THAT was disappointing to me - not Entourage's ending. They made it satisfying.

Anyway, the packaging is good - its the typical DVD set you expect. It has extras which are decent, but nothing special to write home about. I never really care much for the extras though so I'm not the best to ask about those.

The show is great and if you are reading these reviews, you already know you want it - just get it and enjoy it. Just accept that the show is ending after the 8 episodes in this short season - as sad as that is. I will miss Entourage.
My son is an avid fan of entourage and its entire series. It was a good show. Every holiday or birthday he asks for a season. Now Im done- LOL
One of the best seasons yet it was very hard to stop watching i went through the whole thing in 1 sitting, great ending and i cant wait for more to come!
this producer was for my son and he enjoys watching this series as well as his friends.  this is a gift to add to his collection
This is one of the best show ever. I just love this.. getting the show  on amazon is much better than getting on itunes

As the writers kept piling on more and more plot twists and throwing additional obstacles in our main characters' way during Season 8, I had to wonder how they were going to tie up all the loose ends. Answer: very haphazardly. For all its bravado, this is a series that thrived on believable characters.  But in the end they all succumb to unbelievably quick character reversals that leave me wishing Season 8 would have had fewer surprises and more thoughtful scripting.

With all due respect to T.S. Eliot, but that best describes my impression of this final season.  After years of angst between E and Sloan, suddenly they decide they're right for each other.  After years of Vince having short and long-term affairs with countless women, in two episodes he finds his true love, and in one episode Ari walks away from his multi-million dollar business as the only way to save his marriage, and they all just fade into the sunset and hop on luxury private jets.  I expected better.
It seemed like a fitting end to a pretty great show. could it have been better? maybe but it was an enjoyable view.

Not overly exciting, but still really great acting. HBO makes great TV shows, this is the best series though.
-Colin

We have been fans of this show since it started. Have enjoyed watching the build up of the characters. Could not imagine how it could end but the writers did a wonderful job of wrapping up each character line.

This season is smack in the middle in terms of quality.  Not the very best, certainly not the worst, manic as always, a poignant, almost schmaltzy ending, but hey, we earned it right?

It does seem a little that a series that started out skewering Hollywood had a kind of Hollywood ending.

Andrew Dice Clay was my least favorite guest star, surpassing even Gary Busey.
My dvd arrived faster than the expected time. The item was in good condition and the movie disc were clean and not damaged. Overall I am very pleased.

I have been a huge Entourage fan since the first episode and now own all 8 seasons.  There were some amazingly funny episodes in this final season, just like all other seasons, but I have some serious complaints.

First, how absolutely terrible is the ending?  Stop reading if you haven't watched it, but the idea of Vince getting married to a smart educated chick he just met, an untalented Drama making it big, a Turtle bordering on pathetic all season becoming a multi-millionare, and Eric getting back with Sloan after his encounters with her ex-step mom, all happening in the final episode is an insulting conclusion to anyone who watched the show.  The only character's ending which I could even mildly accept was Ari quitting his job to reconcile with Mrs. Ari.

Also, while I love your product, the greedy executives at HBO who continue to break up final seasons need to be fired.  How can there be 16 and 24 episode seasons through a series, but then an 8-episode Season 7 and Season 8?  Soprano's, Sex and the City, and basically every other big HBO series they've produced as done the same thing (or made it Season 6, Part 1 and Part 2).  Way to repay a loyal fan base by screwing them over at the end of every season.

HBO has set the standard and broken the mold all at the same time with their Original Series. With the likes of THE SOPRANOS, THE WIRE, and CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM, ENTOURAGE is a top-tier show that you will love.

Compared to last 3 season entourage was doing great till season 3 then went crap! But this season was pretty good and prob the closet to how the show was and still didn't quite get to it but still not bad!

I thought it was a perfect ending to one of my favorite series. Staying true to the original formula, I enjoyed almost every scene every show. Would strongly recommend to anyone who has seen the show.

I found the product to be of good quality. however, I think the price $2.99 per episode is too high. If there had been a discount on purchasing the entire season it would be much easier to justify the value of this product.

If you've made it to season 8, then you, like me love this show already.  But I think that this last season took the cake.  So many surprises, it perhaps went a little over the top at times but still I loved it.  It was anything but predictable and I'm sad that it had to end.

With this set we now own the entire series on DVD, and it was a great ride.

This last season was classic Entourage, and I enjoyed each episode just as much as the early seasons.  The characters we love were all given some closure.

My only complaint is that there were only 8 half hour episodes on two discs, so this last "season" was very short.

While the 7th Season was very unpleasant to watch, because of the sexcapades, this was the complete antithesis. Entourage ends on a high note with all the characters maturing and meeting life with a higher set of values and adult behavior. It was lots of fun to watch and we felt it was the best Season of all. We applaud the writers for bringing the characters back to earth again with happy endings for all. We all need to strive for understanding and the characters moved along a very nice path to that end.

It started going downhill in S7 when scott caan was given a role as "one of the gang" --- not quite sure how he got the gig but he must be buds with Mark Wahlberg or something. It just did not feel true to life that someone like that would just waltz into the crew and be accepted and in S8 it got worse. 2 late 20 somethings take over a major talent agency from a lifetime industry veteran. The writers were getting lazy at this point.

Then adding Andrew Dice Clay into the mix was just laughable - I guess again Mr Wahlberg was just doing this sad old freak a favor!

Overall a great series and if you watched the first 6 by all means watch the last 2 but be warned the writers got lazy and watching scott caan is painful !
Watching Entourage over the past decade has been truly entertaining.  Every season gets better and ends with a great season 8.  On to the movie

Why are so many people down on the last and final season, Season 8?  Simple answer is they have no imagination.  If you are the type of person that has to see all ends wrapped up, i's dotted and t's crossed, you will not like this.  I know there are rumors of a movie, but the show ended perfectly. I won't spoil it, but characters develop, things change, there are ups, and there are downs.  Wow....just like real life.

Just keep this in mind.... IT'S FICTION!!!! These guys are not real people, they are who you want to be, don't want to be, and wish you were.  That is why the show is fun.  It takes you out of your sofa and put's you in L.A. and in with the "it" crowd.  Use your imagination to cross the t's and dot the i's.

As much as I want to see a movie, I'm not sure it can ever live up to what I think they are all doing today.
Best show I've ever seen.
Great product, love it! As described and fast shipping!
I loved everything about this series, the ending as well. I watch for entertainment and to kind of vicariously visit the area I grew up in.
Best show!
good entertainment. The last episode was a bit too wrapped up in a nice little package with a bow, but...eh...it was nice to see a happy ending. At least it didn't end like the Sopranos!
I wish there were more seasons.
Wrapped up great.

I only recently watched this show but I loved it! My favorite character by far is agent Ari Gold! He is such an awesome character and adds a lot of laughs to each scene he is in. This is a great show that follows a group of close friends as they try to make it in LA/Hollywood. Binge-worthy, for sure.

I loved this show from beginning to end. I watched all 8 seasons in 4 days. The only complaint i would have is the lack of a real conclusion. It just kind of ends and i am dissapointed in that. Still loved the show!
